content.description:
Crux is right off the ground (may feel harder than 11 until you get the sequence), then sustained to the top. Eases off at the end in the crack.

The white face broken by two large ledges right of Major Attitude.
Bolts, and at least one cam for the very end, a #2 works for me.

Although one of the only routes requiring a full rack at Higgy Land, this is one of the best. The gear can be poor, bring some slings. A bolt takes some of the fear out of the crux but it would still be a huge whip if the gear pulled. Pumpy with a steep crux.  
  Both free ascents to date were worked out on TR first, but watch the swing in the first half, as you can hit the wall on the other side.

Smack in the middle of the crag, up the steep hill.
Single rack to #4 Camalot.

Bolted to give the area a 5.7, this route isn't anything to write home about but is great for beginners to learn to lead. Closely bolted. Originally the thin crack, 'Skin mag', was done on gear as a 5.6, and the wide crack to the right is a 5.4. Rarely ever lead on gear and very short, this line now sees traffic and takes a sporttier path up the face.

In between the Destruction zone and Gappage zone on a short rouded out-cropping, to the left of Appetite for Destruction.
5 bolts.  Tree to anchor, or just walk off.

Climbs the leaning arete feature left of Major Attitude. Thin and technical climbing with an immediate balancy crux, and a final bouldery finish. Final crux can be avoided by moving right and into the over hanging finish of Major Attitude, which is still a very quality ending.  To set up a TR, bring long slings to extend the chain anchors of Major Attitude. Route was not bolted due to the thin nature of the rock.

TR only, for now.

Given a broad range in the guide, this area includes routes just left of the Destruction zone, climbs up the steep hill and on the bluff to the right of the ledge. Two climbs are classics and worth seeking out, but require gear.
